message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest renal colic, and gross hematuria further supports this diagnosis. Non-contrast CT of the abdomen and pelvis is the best imaging tool to diagnose and locate the obstructing stone. Contrast CT is not recommended in patients with acute kidney injury or suspected allergic reactions to contrast agents. Renal ultrasound is not the best initial imaging study for renal colic, but it can be considered to localize the stone if CT is not available or contraindicated. Supine abdominal radiograph is less sensitive and specific than CT for diagnosing renal colic.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest renal colic, and a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis without contrast is the initial imaging study of choice. Renal ultrasound is less sensitive than CT and is not sufficient to rule out other causes of flank pain. A contrast CT would be indicated if there is concern for obstruction or infection, but should be avoided in cases of suspected renal colic due to the risk of contrast-induced nephropathy. A supine abdominal radiograph is not sensitive or specific enough to diagnose renal colic.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of renal colic, including severe pain, nausea, and vomiting, with gross hematuria on urinalysis indicating a kidney stone. Non-contrast CT of the abdomen and pelvis is the best initial imaging modality to diagnose and determine the size and location of the stone. Contrast CT and ultrasound are also options but not the best initial step. Supine abdominal radiograph is not sensitive enough to diagnose kidney stones.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination suggest the presence of a kidney stone (renal colic). Non-contrast CT of the abdomen and pelvis is the recommended initial imaging modality for patients with suspected renal colic, as it can accurately diagnose the presence and location of a stone. Contrast CT may not be necessary and can delay diagnosis and treatment, while renal ultrasound is not as sensitive or specific as CT for detecting stones. Supine abdominal radiograph also has low sensitivity compared to CT.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including severe, intermittent, colicky left flank pain with hematuria, suggest renal colic, most likely caused by a kidney stone. Non-contrast CT of the abdomen and pelvis is the most appropriate next step in management as it can accurately determine the presence and size of a stone. A contrast CT may be contraindicated due to the risk of contrast-induced nephropathy in patients with underlying renal disease. Renal ultrasound has a low sensitivity for detecting stones and is not the best initial imaging modality. Supine abdominal radiograph may show a radio-opaque kidney stone but has lower sensitivity and is not the best initial imaging modality.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest acute renal colic, and a non-contrast CT scan is the imaging study of choice to confirm the diagnosis and to evaluate for other causes of flank pain. The radiograph and renal ultrasound are less specific for this diagnosis, and a contrast CT is contraindicated due to the possibility of worsening renal function.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Acute-onset flank pain, colicky pain, nausea, vomiting, and hematuria suggest a kidney stone. Non-contrast CT of the abdomen and pelvis is the best initial imaging modality to evaluate for kidney stones. Contrast can obscure a small stone or cause contrast-induced nephrotoxicity, while a renal ultrasound is not as sensitive as CT. A supine abdominal radiograph is not sensitive enough to identify kidney stones.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest renal colic, and the hematuria suggests the presence of a stone. A non-contrast CT of the abdomen and pelvis is the most appropriate next step in management as it can confirm the diagnosis and determine the size and location of the stone. A contrast CT may worsen kidney function in patients with renal insufficiency, which is a possibility in the patient with underlying hypertension and diabetes mellitus. A renal ultrasound may miss smaller stones and is not as sensitive or specific as CT for detecting stones. A supine abdominal radiograph is not sensitive for detecting small or radiolucent stones.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest renal colic, and a non-contrast CT of the abdomen and pelvis is the best imaging modality for diagnosing urolithiasis. A contrast CT may be contraindicated due to the risk of worsening renal failure in a severely dehydrated patient. Renal ultrasound and supine abdominal radiograph are not the best initial test for diagnosing urolithiasis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest the patient has acute flank pain, which is often caused by kidney stones. The presence of gross hematuria confirms the diagnosis of urolithiasis. A non-contrast CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis is the preferred imaging study to diagnose urolithiasis. Other options such as contrast CT or ultrasound may not provide as accurate diagnosis or may not be as readily available.
